Event category: What’s the difference between a warning and a caution? I recently received a police warning for harassment. I understand that this is different to a caution, although the police did say that I now have a local police record. Can you explain the difference between the two and what a 'local' police record is please? Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share on Email Send via Whatsapp Send via SMS Views 67,394 There is no difference between a caution and a warning. A caution can be given to anyone over 10 years old for a minor offence such as graffiti. Although a caution doesn’t count as a criminal conviction and is considered ‘spent’ immediately under the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974 it will probably show up in the future on DBS checks (previously known as a CRB), particularly enhanced DBSs. If it is a verbal warning then the officer will make a note of the incident and then update the forces control room of the outcome in order for the incident to be closed on the record. Yes this indicates that your name will appear on a computer record held by your local police force, but again this is not in any way a criminal record. The only way to know what is held locally or nationally is to request a copy of your information. Next Steps Chat about this subject on our Discussion Boards. Need help but confused where to go locally? Download our StepFinder iPhone app to find local support services quickly. Tags:cautions| criminal record job applications| DBS checks| finding work with criminal record Comments by Vanillagtm.click
